Tasks
  • Docs »
  • Table
  • View page source

Table¶

The table shows all of your tasks. This includes tasks:

  • Personally assigned to you
  • Assigned to you because you have the corresponding role in your user data

The information contained in the table is determined by two factors:

  • The task type
  • Your individual settings

When you select a task in the table (by clicking it), the corresponding details are displayed in the detail area.

Columns¶

Changing the column width¶

You can change the column width directly in the table.

To change the column width, move the cursor to the right-hand side of the column header. Once you are in the correct position, a vertical blue bar will appear and the cursor will change to a horizontal double-arrow. The width of the column can then be increased or decreased.

Ideally, you should carry out this function in conjunction with the other settings for the table.

Column header¶

The task type determines the content of the columns. The column headers described below can be seen in the default setting and are applicable for all of the standard task types.

Unread¶

Unread tasks are indicated by:

  • Bold font
  • A yellow dot in the Unread? cell

You can change the status of the task to Read directly in the cell.

Click the yellow dot to mark a task as Read. The yellow dot will be hidden and the bold font will disappear.

Click the empty space where the yellow dot was displayed to change the status of the task back to Unread. The yellow dot appears and the task is highlighted in bold.

Type¶

Displays the task type icon. The name of the task type is displayed in a tooltip.

Name¶

Shows the name of the task. Usually, a brief description of the task is included.

If the name of the task is longer than the width of the column, the full name of the task can be seen in the context unit of information in the detail area. In the Context unit of information, the name of the task will be displayed in a tooltip if it is too long.

Status¶

Shows the current status of the task.

To change the status of a task, highlight the task and

  • Select a new status directly in this cell using the triangle symbol or
  • Call up the operation Status change in the Editing options area.

Due on¶

Shows the due date of the task. If the due date has passed, the date will be highlighted in red.

Tags¶

Tags can be used to record additional personal information relating to tasks. This additional information may help the user to classify, group or sort tasks more accurately.

If a task does not contain any tags, the placeholder “Add Tag(s)” appears in the cell.

  1. Click in the Tags cell and enter your text.
  2. You can record several tags for the same task. Separate the individual tags with a comma.
  3. Once your tag is complete, press the Enter key.

Note

You can choose a name for the tags as required. To ensure that the information is sorted or grouped in a meaningful way, it is better to avoid synonyms and to use standardized spelling.

Each tag is displayed in alphabetical order in a blue text field. Duplicate tags can only be entered once.

Overdue?¶

Indicates whether a task is overdue.

Overdue tasks appear in this cell with a red square.

The Overdue indicator is primarily used for grouping or sorting.

Responsible¶

Shows the parties responsible for a task.

Either a specific user is responsible for the task or the responsibility is assigned to a role. If the responsibility is assigned to a role, the task is visible to all users who are assigned this role.

This column allows the user to filter out tasks that are not personally assigned to them, for example.

CONTACT Tasks only shows you (or the user who appears in the menu bar) the tasks for which you are fully responsible or the tasks for which you share responsibility due to your role.

Priority¶

Shows the priority of a task.

There are three levels of priority for tasks:

  • High
  • Medium
  • Low

Effort¶

Shows the estimated effort for a task.

Progress¶

Shows the percentage of the task currently completed.

Priority (calculated)¶

The actual priority is calculated using a formula.

The calculation takes into account the following factors:

  • The explicit priority
  • The effort
  • The progress
  • The due date(deadline)

Ideally, when the value produced by the formula is used to sort the tasks in descending order of priority (calculated), this accurately reflects the personal processing sequence.

Note

To provide the optimum benefit for the user, the administrator can adapt the formula in line with requirements.
